title: Varadkar tells Johnson UK’s backstop alternatives not ‘realistic’
text:
Irish Taoiseach Leo Varadkar (R) speaks to the media ahead of his meeting with British Prime Minister Boris Johnson on September 9, 2019 in Dublin, Ireland | Charles McQuillan/Getty Images Varadkar tells Johnson UK’s backstop alternatives not ‘realistic’ Dublin cannot ‘agree to the replacement of a legal guarantee with a promise’ said Irish prime minister.

LONDON — The EU has yet to see "realistic" proposals from Boris Johnson's government for breaking the Brexit impasse, Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said, ahead of the two leaders' first meeting in Dublin.

On the central dispute over the Irish border, Varadkar said that Dublin could not "agree to the replacement of a legal guarantee with a promise” and reiterated the backstop plan — which Johnson wants to abolish — was a "critical part" of the Brexit deal, removal of which would be tantamount to no-deal.

Johnson and Varadkar held talks in Dublin this morning, but both men acknowledged in a short press conference that no breakthrough is expected today.

Johnson insisted that there were "practical issues that can be resolved" to obviate the need for checks at the border when the U.K. leaves the EU, citing familiar piecemeal measures such as trusted trade schemes and technological fixes. He also cited a U.K. commitment to preserve an all Ireland approach to rules governing agricultural trade. Johnson said such measures would go "a long way" to getting a solution but conceded there were "still other issues to resolve."

However, Varadkar made clear the proposals did not go far enough to remove the need for the backstop, a legal fallback that would see the U.K. remain in a de-facto customs union with the EU.

“The backstop continues to be a critical component of the Withdrawal Agreement unless and until alternatives are found," he said adding that such alternatives “must be realistic, legally binding and workable, and we have not received such proposals to date.”

Playing to Johnson's well-known affection for the classics, Varadkar said that even if there was a deal the U.K. faced a "Herculean task" negotiating free trade agreements with the EU and the U.S. simultaneously, but pledged that Ireland would be its "ally, your Athena" in doing so if Brexit went smoothly.

Johnson faced tough questioning, with one reporter asking whether his comment last week that he would rather be "dead in a ditch" than delay Brexit suggested that he did not understand the high stakes in Ireland and Northern Ireland, where fears that Brexit could foster a continued rise in political violence are widespread.

“Everybody in the U.K. and in Ireland understands the fantastic political importance and sensitivity of the border," he said and repeated his unilateral pledge not to introduce any checks on the U.K. side of the border.

Johnson insisted that he was still determined to get a deal and that for Brexit to take place without an agreement ““would be a failure of state craft for which we would all be responsible.”

On talks to restore the power-sharing devolved government in Northern Ireland, Varadkar said that Dublin would oppose any imposition of direct rule from Westminster but that were such a course of action to be taken, would seek a "consultative role in any big decisions taken in Northern Ireland.”

A decision to impose direct rule may be needed soon, U.K. Northern Ireland Secretary Julian Smith suggested last week, to ensure that Northern Ireland has political direction and decision-making to allow it to manage the likely disruption that would result from Brexit should the U.K. leave on its planned date of October 31.
description: Dublin cannot ‘agree to the replacement of a legal guarantee with a promise’ said Irish prime minister.
